title: 108_hr20
content: The "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 2003" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. It provides general authority for capitalization grants and outlines capitalization grants agreements. The "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 2003" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act by updating requirements for construction of treatment works and architectural and engineering contracts. The "Clean Water Infrastructure Financing Act of 2003" updates requirements for construction contracts related to program management, feasibility studies, design, and engineering services. Contracts must be awarded based on qualifications, with no proprietary interest conferred to the United States. Guidance for small systems includes simplified procedures to be implemented within a year. The Administrator will assist States in establishing simplified procedures for small systems to obtain assistance under this title. A manual will be published to aid small systems in obtaining assistance, with a definition of 'small system' as serving a population of 10,000 or less. SEC. 4. WATER POLLUTION CONTROL REVOLVING FUNDS. Activities eligible for assistance under the Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds include construction of treatment works, lake protection programs, and management programs to improve or protect water quality of navigable waters. Activities eligible for assistance under the Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds include implementation of conservation and management plans, restoration of riparian areas, beneficial reuse of wastewater, water pollution prevention plans, land acquisition for mitigation requirements, enhancement of treatment works security, and treatment works replacement and rehabilitation. The Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds can be used for replacement and rehabilitation of treatment works to address sewer overflows. The fund balance is available indefinitely for providing financial assistance, and fees charged by states can be used for fund administration. Loan guarantees can also be provided for similar revolving funds. The Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds can be used for developing and implementing innovative technologies. Administrative expenses are capped at $400,000 per year or \1/2\ percent per year of the current valuation of the fund. Technical and planning assistance is provided to small systems. The Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds can be used for providing technical and planning assistance to small systems, including financial management, user fee analysis, budgeting, and facility operation. Grants are also available for financially distressed communities. Construction Assistance under Section 603(g) of the Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds Act prioritizes projects on the State's list for publicly owned treatment works. Treatment works treating municipal waste water or domestic sewage are eligible for assistance. Financially distressed communities in a State may receive grants equal to 25 percent of the difference in funding if the Administrator has over $1,400,000,000 available for water pollution control projects. Financially distressed communities in a State may receive grants equal to 25 percent of the difference in funding if the Administrator has over $1,400,000,000 available for water pollution control projects. The grants must be used to improve water quality, and the State can give priority to financially distressed communities for loans. Amounts for grants remain available until expended. The term 'financially distressed community' is defined as any community meeting affordability criteria set by the State for loans from the water pollution control revolving fund. The Administrator may provide information to assist States in establishing these criteria. SEC. 5. ASSET MANAGEMENT. Title VI (33 U.S.C. 1381 et seq.) is amended to provide technical and financial assistance for inventorying, evaluating, and developing maintenance plans for treatment works assets. $10,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008: $3 billion for 2004, $4 billion for 2005, $5 billion for 2006, $6 billion for 2007, and $7 billion for 2008.
